div.p: If the ſpittle which they void by coughing that are affected with a Conſumption, do ſtink vehemently being caſt upon the coals, and the hairs of the head do fall off, it is a deadly ſign.

p.hi: For the more faculties are weakned in ſo much the worſer caſe the Patient is.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: If a flux of the belly happen to them, which have their hair falling away by a Conſumption; death is neer at hand.

p.hi:
Becauſe it proceeding from weakneſs alſo, it ſhews a further weakening
of the natural faculties.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: Thoſe which cough forth frothy blood, do retch and draw the ſame out of the Lungs.

p.hi: And it is part of the very ſubſtance and fleſh of the Lungs.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: If a flux of the belly happen to him which is in a Conſumption it is deadly.

p.hi: This affirms what was ſaid before Aph. 12 and moreover that a flux of the belly added to a Conſumption, is alone ſufficient to kill without falling away of the hair.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: Thoſe which are infected with an impoſthume by a Pluriſie, if they be purged from the corrupt matter within forty days after the breaking of the impoſthume are cured, or otherwiſe they paſs into a Conſumption.

p.hi: For the matter will otherwiſe be ſo putrified that it will periſh the lungs

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: Hot water too often uſed, bringeth theſe diſcommodities: tenderneſs of the fleſh, diſtemperature of the ſinews, heavineſs, and ſtupefaction of the mind, fluxes of blood, faintings and ſwounings; and to theſe things ſucceeds death

p.hi: Hippocrates here wiſheth us to ſhun; the exceſſive uſe of any thing, though never ſo temperate.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: The uſe of cold water, bringeth Convulſions, diſtentions or Cramps, blackneſs, and cold Aguiſh ſhakings.

p.hi: This is alſo not of the uſe ſimply but of the immoderate uſe of cold water.

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p:
Cold water is hurtful to the bones, teeth, ſinews, brain, and
marrow of the back. But that which is hot is good and profitable.

p.hi: All the parts here rehearſed are by nature the coldeſt.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: We muſt heat thoſe things which are over cold, except thoſe which pour forth or are inclined to pour forth blood abundantly.

p.hi: For when there are more diſeaſes then one coupled together, we muſt make haſt to cure that firſt which is moſt urgent.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: Cold water biteth and nippeth Ulcers, hardeneth the skin, hindereth a ſoreneſs from maturation of the corrupt matter, cauſeth blackneſs, bringeth forth cold ſhivering fits of Agues, Convulſions, and diſtentions of the ſinews.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm relates ſome other hurts which cold water doth.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: Notwithſtanding there is ſome time when in the Cramp without an ulcer in a wel fleſht young man in the midſt of Summer, plentiful pouring out of cold water, doth call back the heat, and ſo the heat diſſolves the Cramp.

p.hi: This is not done by any vertue of its, but accidentally by drawing the natural heat outward in ſuch well fleſht young men.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p:
Hot water yieldeth unto us a great token of ſecurity and ſafety, when it cauſeth ſuppuration, yet not in all Ulcers. It ſoftneth and mollifieth the skin, and maketh it thin, it doth appeaſe pain, it mitigateth and aſſawageth cold ſhakeings, Convulſions and diſtentions: It diſſolveth the heavineſs of the head: It profiteth broken bones very much; eſpecially if they be
bare without fleſh, and principally in the head, if they be ulcerated: it profiteth thoſe things which are mortified, and ulcerated through cold, eating Ulcers in the Fundament, privy members, womb, and bladder. To all thoſe hot water is a friend, and of good judgement; but cold water is an enemy and deſtroyer.

p.hi: Not in all ulcers, becauſe ſome wil not be brought to ſupuration by heat

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p:
We muſt uſe cold water to thoſe ſores from whence blood doth iſſue, or is about to iſſue, yet not to the ſame place, but neer to it. And if any inflammation or burning of the parts, do incline to a red and bloody color, with freſh cleer blood, apply cold water to them, but if the inflamations be inveterate and old it maketh them black. It helpeth the inflammation called
Eryſipelas, if it be not ulcerated, for if it be it hurteth it.

p.hi: Now he relates what things cold water is good for.

div.head: APH. 24.
div.p: Cold things, as Snow and Ice are hurtful to the breaſt, they procure coughs, they cauſe ruptures of the veyns, and produce Rheumes.

p.hi: He hath ſpoken of the effects of cold water, now he ſpeaks of the hurt which other cold things do.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: Cold water poured out abundantly, doth eaſe and diminiſh the tumors and pains of the joynts, which are without ulceration. And alſo gouty ſwellings and pains, and Convulſions for the moſt part, and diſſolveth the dolor, and diminiſheth it. for a ſmall benumming hath the force of diſſolving and putting away of pan.

p.hi:
The end of this, phoriſm is a reaſon
of the whole Aphoriſms aſſertion. As if he ſhould ſay a little benumming puts away pain; cold water benumeth, therefore, &c▪

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: Water that is quickly made hot, and quickly cools, is moſt light.

p.hi: He means not by weight, but he ſpeaks of that water which doth not long burthen the belly, and quickly paſſeth through.

div.head: APH. 27
div.p: It is good for them who deſire to drink in the night, to fall aſleep when they are very thirſty.

p.hi: Becauſe ſleep concocts the food, which being concocted ingenders blood, which nouriſhes and moiſtens the parts of the body.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: A Fumigation of odoriferous ſpices brings forth womens terms: and would be alſo profitable for many other things, if it did not breed heavineſs of the head.

p.hi: For it doth excite the expulſive faculty of the womb, and open the obſtructions of the veines which touch the womb.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: Thou ſhalt pruge a woman with child if neceſſity require, the 4th. month after conception, until the 7th month, though thoſe that come neer the 7th, not ſo much: but the conception being younger or elder thou ſhalt abſtain.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm is the ſame with the firſt of the fourth Section.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: A woman with child, a vein being opened aborteth, and ſo much the rather if the conception be of any bigneſs.

p.hi: Becauſe it taketh away part of its food, namely the conceptions.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: It is pernicious and deadly if a woman great with child be taken with any ſharp diſeaſe.

p.hi: For large feeding will kill the mother by increaſing the diſeaſe, and little ſtore of food will ſtarve the conception.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: A woman is cured from vomiting blood, by her monethly terms iſſuing forth.

p.hi: By the Phyſicians drawing down the blood to the lower parts.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: A flux of blood at the noſe is good for a woman whoſe monthly terms do fail contrary to the courſe of nature.

p.hi: For if this happen not contrary to the courſe of nature, ſuch a failing is nothing.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: If the belly be very laxative and looſe to a woman with child, there is danger fo abortment.

p.hi:
Becauſe the food is not diſtributed to the liver and other parts of the
body, ſo that the food is taken away from the conception as when ſhe is let blood.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: Sneeſing happening to a woman grieved with ſuffocations of the womb, or that hath a difficult deliverance, is good.

p.hi: For by a vehement ſhaking of nature, it excites it, redintegrates the natural heat which was almoſt extinguiſhed, and ſhakes off ſuch noxious humors as hanged upon ſome part of the body.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: The monethly courſes being diſcoloured, and not coming forth always in the ſame manner and time, declare a purgation to be neceſſary for the woman.

p.hi: To purge thoſe humors which cauſe the diſcoloration, and the alteration of time.

div.head: APH▪ 37.
div.p: If the paps be ſuddenly extenuated and become lank, to a woman with child abortment doth follow

p.hi: This alſo happeneth, for want of food for the conceived child.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: If one of the dugs be extenuated and become lank to a woman conceived with child with twins, ſhe bringeth forth one of them before the due time; and if the right dug become ſlender, ſhe bringeth forth the male, if the left, the female.

p.hi: For likewiſe the male conceptions lye on the right ſide, the female on the left: as is ſet down Aph. 48.

div.head: APH▪ 39.
div.p: If any woman, neither with child nor having been delivered of child have milk in her breaſts, her monethly courſes have failed her.

p.hi: The blood which ſhould have turned to monethly terms, turning to milk in the breaſts.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: Women in whoſe dugs there is blood heaped together, wil be mad

p.hi: For that blood is very bilious, which ſtriking up into the head, cauſeth madneſs.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If you will know whether a woman have conceived or no, give her a potion of hony and water mixed together going to ſleep, and if ſhe feel gripings and wringings of the belly, ſhe hath conceived, if ſhe do not, ſhe hath not conceived

p.hi: For ſuch a potion is very windy, and the woman having conceived her womb doth preſs down, and keep together the intrails.

div.head: APH. 42
div.p: If a woman conceived with child, bear a male ſhe is freſh and well-coloured, if ſhe bare a female ſhe is ill-colored.

p.hi:
This Aphoriſm is one of thoſe
which for the moſt part are true, though not always.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: If the inflammation called Eryſipelas be bred in the womb, if the woman be with child, it proves deadly.
One reaſon is becauſe the chief cure for an Eryſipelas is letting of blood and that muſt not be done to a woman with child for fear of an abortment, Aph. 30.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: Thoſe women which are very lean contrary to nature, and do bear children, do ſuffer untimely deliverance until they grow fatter

p.hi: Becauſe that food which ſhould be for the child in the womb, goes to the nouriſhing of the mother.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p:
Thoſe women which being reaſonable fat, and make abortion the ſecond or third month without
any manifeſt cauſe, have the ends of thoſe veſſels which come to the womb called acetabula or Cotylidons full of a pituitous or phlegmy humor, neither can they contain the conception coming to any weight, but they being broken it falleth down.

p.hi: Wherby ſhe muſt of neceſſity abort

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Thoſe which are fatter then nature requires and cannot conceive have the orifice of the womb compreſſed and cloſed together by the fat Call of the guts, and cannot until they grow leaner.

p.hi: He means the inward orifice of the womb for it hath two.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: If the womb ſhall Apoſthumate in that part where it lieth neer the hip or huckle-bone, it muſt be cured with tents dipped in a liquid medicine called in Greek Emmoton.

p.hi: It muſt be thus cured the ſore being firſt broken either by art or nature.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: Men children for the moſt part lye on the right ſide of the womb and females on the left ſide.

p.hi: This is becauſe the womb is warmer on the right ſide, by reaſon of its vicinity to the Liver.

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: A medicine procuring ſneezing put into the noſtrils doth drive and force out the Secundine, ſo that you ſtop the noſtrils and mouth, cloſe with the hand.

p.hi: Which if it remained would putrifie there, and with the ſtench offend the head.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: If a woman will ſtay her courſes apply a very great cupping-glaſs under her breaſts.

p.hi: For there be veins which come up thither from the inferior parts.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: Thoſe women which are conceived with child, have the orifice of the womb ſhut and cloſed up.

p.hi: That the air may not get in and corrupt the ſeed, and that the heat of the womb may not get out.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: If milk flow plentifully out of the dugs of a woman bearing a child in her womb it ſignifieth that the child is weak: but if the paps be hard and ſtiff, they declare a ſtronger conception.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſhews in the former part that the child is not able to draw it for his own nutriment. But when they are ſolid it ſhews it hath nutriment enough, and that which ſuperabounds goes to the breaſts, and is there turned into milk.

div.head: APH 53.
div.p:
The dugs and paps become ſlender and lank to thoſe women
which ſhall abort: but contrarily if they become hard, pain ſhall moleſt the paps, hips, eys, or knees, but they ſhall not ſuffer abortment.

p.hi: Becauſe of the ſuperfluous matter which is brought thither from the womb.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Thoſe women which have the mouth of the womb hard, muſt of neceſſity have it ſhut up.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm had been better placed immmediately after the Aphoriſm 51.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Child-bearing women which are taken with Feavers, or are brought to a low ſtate without any manifeſt cauſe, do bring forth their birth painfully, and with danger: or are in danger of life by an untimely deliverance.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſhews a great weakneſs or imbecility in them.

div.head: APH 56.
div.p: If a Convulſion, or ſwouning happen to a woman, in her flux of monethly terms, it is an evil thing

p.hi: If they be vehement or laſt long, it may be deadly becauſe the womb is exhauſted and draws all the noble parts into a ſimpathy with it.

div.head: APH. 57.
div.p: Womens terms flowing immoderately, diſeaſes are ingendred; and being ſuppreſt or ſtopt, diſeaſes happen from the womb.

p.hi: By their immoderate evacuation, the whole body is cooled, and its forces weakened, if they be ſtopt, in progreſs of time, excremental humors gather together in the womb.

div.head: APH. 58.
div.p:
The ſtrangurie or dropping out of the urine doth happen by the inflammation of the ſtraight gut,
and likewiſe of the womb, or if the reins be ulcerated. But if the liver be inflamed, the Hicket ſucceeds.

p.hi: By reaſon of the vicinity of the bladder to the ſtraigbt gut and the womb, and becauſe of the purulent matter of the reins paſſing through the bladder: and the hicket is cauſed by a high inflammation of the liver becauſe it ſwells the liver, and oppreſſes the ventricle, and the bilious humor falling from the liver comes into the ventricle.

div.head: APH. 59.
div.p: If a woman do not conceive, and thou wouldeſt know if ſhe ſhall conceive at all, let her be wrapped round about with clothes, & make a fume under the lower parts, and if the ſcent be perceived to paſs through her body to her noſtrils, and her mouth, know that ſhe is not barren by any default in her ſelf.

p.hi: Becauſe then the body is cleer of all vitious humors, and the womb it ſelf is in a good temper.

div.head: APH. 60.
div.p: If the monethly purgations keep their courſe in a woman that is with child, it is impoſſible that the conception ſhould be well.

p.hi: Becauſe it wants its aliment and food, being fed by that menſtruous blood al the while it is in the womb.

div.head: APH. 61.
div.p: If a womans monthly courſes ſtop, and ſhe have neither ſhivering cold nor Ague coming upon her, and ſhe loath her meat, make account that ſhe is conceived.

p.hi: For at the firſt conceiving of a woman, the child cannot make uſe of thoſe courſes for its food.

div.head: APH. 62.
div.p:
Thoſe women which have their womb cold and dry do not conceive, nor thoſe which have it over
moiſt, for the ſeed is extinguiſht and periſht in them. Alſo thoſe women cannot conceive which have thoſe places over dry and hot, for the ſeed corrupts for want of nouriſhment. But thoſe women which have obtained a moderate temperature of the places in reſpect of both the oppoſitions and contrarieties they are fruitful.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm by right ſhould be placed next to the 59 Aph.

div.head: APH. 63.
div.p:
The ſame conſideration and reaſon is likewiſe to be reſpected in men men, for either through the ſpongy ſubſtance of the body, the ſpirits are diſſipated and ſcattered abroad ſo that the ſeed cannot be caſt forth; or elſe the humor doth not iſſue forth becauſe of its groſneſs or thickneſs; or elſe becauſe of coldneſs it doth not grow hot,
to be collected in its proper place▪ or by the means of heat, the very ſelf ſame thing may happen.
This Aphoriſm is held to be ſpurious, and none of Hippocrates, both by Galen and others.

div.head: APH. 64.
div.p:
It is not good to give milk to thoſe who are troubled with the head-ach, or with Agues, nor to thoſe who are troubled with flatus Hypocondriacus, nor to thoſe who are troubled with thirſt. It is alſo naught for them which avoid cholerick excrements downwards, or to thoſe which have ſharp Feavers, or have had ſome copious evacuation of blood. But it is good for thoſe which are in a Conſumption, ſo they be not troubled with any vehement Feaver. It is alſo good for long lingering and mild Agues, ſo there be none of the ſore ſpoken of ſignes. And
thoſe who are brought low without any apperant reaſon or occaſion,
The particular reaſons for theſe particular aſſertions may be ſeen at large in Galen, Fuchſius, and Heurnius Comments, which would be too long to reherſe here.

div.head: APH. 65
div.p: They are ſeldom troubled with Convulſions or madneſs, which have apparent tumors with their ulcers. But Convulſions and diſtentions happen to them to whom the tumors ſhall ſuddenly vaniſh away, if they happen on the hinder part of the body. But if they happen on the fore part, there happeneth madneſs, vehement pain of the ſide▪ ſuppuration or ſpitting of matter, and the bloody-flux.

p.hi:
Becauſe the humors reſide there. And if they go away by degrees alſo
there is no danger for it ſhews, that the noxious humors are ſhaken off and diſſolved.

div.head: APH. 66.
div.p: If no tumor nor ſwelling appear in great and bad wounds, it is a great evil

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies a paſſing of the noxious humors to the principal parts.

div.head: APH. 67.
div.p: Soft tumors are good, raw and indigeſted ones evil.

p.hi: Becauſe the firſt ſignifie there is a concoction, and in the ſecond there is none.

div.head: APH. 68.
div.p: To one who hath a pain in the hinder part of his head, the vena recta in the fore-head being opened doth good.

The vena recta is that which is over againſt that which is oppoſite to that vein which nouriſheth
the part which is evil affected, ſo the opening of it doth both evacuate and divert the noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 69.
div.p: Cold ſhakings and ſhiverings for the moſt part do begin to women from the loyns, and through the back come to the head. But to men they do rather begin in the back part then in the forepart, as from the hinder part of the thighes and from the elbows; the rarity and thinneſs of the skin is a token thereof, which thing, the hair there growing, doth declare and manifeſt.

p.hi: For the thicker the skin is, the l • ſs will hair grow upon it.

div.head: APH. 70.
div.p: Thoſe which are taken with a Quartan Ague are not at all taken with Convulſions: but if before they have been taken, upon the coming of the quartan, they are delivered.

p.hi: He means here ſuch Convulſions as come by repletion of the nervous parts, with thin and pituitous humors, which by a quartan are both expelled and concocted

div.head: APH. 71.
div.p: Thoſe who have their skin acide, and dry, die without ſweating, but thoſe who have a looſe and open skin, end their life with ſweat.

p.hi: He ſpeaks here of thoſe who have a Feaver.

div.head: APH. 72.
div.p: Thoſe that are diſeaſed with the Jaundies are not much moleſted, with windineſs.

p.hi: By reaſon of the heat and ſtrength of the parts belonging to the ſtomack, which cauſeth them to concoct the food fully and perfectly.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This Section doth almoſt altogether concern that part of the Art which foretelleth good and evil things to happen in diſeaſes.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: IN a long lubricity and ſlipperineſs of the guts, if a ſoweriſh belching do happen, which was not before, it is a good ſign.

p.hi: For it ſignifies, that now the food remains a while in the ſtomack, till ſuch time at leaſt as it begins to concoct.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p:
Thoſe which have ther noſtrils more moiſt then others by nature,
and their ſeed alſo do enjoy their health but badly; but thoſe which have the contrary properties, are more healthful.

p.hi: By the noſtrils he means the brains which purge that way, and by the humidity of the Seed, the humidity of the whole body, the ſeed coming from the blood.

div.head: APH. 3.
div.p: In long fluxes of the bowels, loathing of meat is evil, and with a Feaver it is worſer.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies a mortification of the nouriſhing faculty.

div.head: APH. 4.
div.p: Ulcers which are every way ſmooth and bald.

p.hi: Becauſe of an evil humor lying in the bottom, which eats up the roots of the hair, as ſalt earth doth the herbs roots which grow on it.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p:
In the pains of the ſides, breaſt,
and other parts, we muſt conſider whether they increaſe or differ much, or keep at a ſtay.

p.hi: Whither they differ namely in their kind, or in their vehemency, whether they be pricking▪ ſtretching, or provoking.

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: The diſeaſes and infirmities of the Kidneys and Bladder are of hard and difficult curation in old men.
• hich old age begins at fifty years which Hippocrates confirms in his ſixt Book Epidemion where he ſaith he never ſaw or knew an ulcer of the reins or bladder cured after fifty years of age.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Dolours and pains of the beſly being aloft and in the upper part are more light & eaſie, thoſe which are not aloft are more vehement.

p.hi: We muſt underſtand this word aloft not according to the length and height of the body, but according to its depth and thickneſs, ſo be thoſe which are not aloft, he means thoſe which are next to the back.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p: Ulcers or ſores in the body of thoſe which are diſeaſed with the dropſie, are not eaſily cured.

p.hi: For an ulcer cannot be cured until it be exactly dryed, which cannot eaſily be done in thoſe who have the dropſie, by reaſon of their ſuperabundant humidity.

div.head: APH. 9.
div.p: Broad wheals are not very full of itching.

p.hi: For they are not bred by ſuch hot humors as thoſe which are narrow and high.

div.head: APH. 10.
div.p:
Corrupt matter, water or blood
iſſuing out, by the noſtrils, mouth or ears, diſſolveth and cureth a vehement and grievous head-ach.

p.hi: If that the pain proceed from inflammation, or abundance of crude humors gathered in the head, for if it proceed from other cauſes, there muſt be other cures.

div.head: APH. 11▪
div.p: The Haemorroides happening to thoſe, which are troubled with melancholly and pain of the Kidneys are good.

p.hi: Both by reaſon of the evacuation, and becauſe they evacuate ſuch humors as ought to be evacuated.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: Unleſs in the cures of Haemorroides which have long continued there be one vein kept open, it is to be feared that a Dropſie or Convulſion will ſhortly▪ follow.

p.hi: That nature may by that means purge out thoſe evil humors which remain.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: The Hick •• troubling us is put away by ſneezing.

p.hi: If the ſaid Hicket was cauſed by fulneſs For by ſneezing not only the brain: but the ſtomack alſo, by reaſon of the nerves derived unto it, is vehemently ſhaken, whereby the humors exciting the Hicket are evacuated.

div.head: APH▪ 14.
div.p: If in him who hath a Dropſie if the water flow from the veins into the belly, the diſeaſe is diſſolved.

p.hi: If Nature or Phyſick make evacuation of it from thence.

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: Vomiting coming by the meer benefit of nature diſſolveth and riddeth away a long flux or looſneſs of the belly.

p.hi: By reaſon of the retraction and drawing back of the humors which 〈◊〉 downward.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: A looſeneſs of the belly, to one afflicted with a Pluriſie or inflammation of the Lungs is an evil thing.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies the liver to be ſo affected, by the conſent of thoſe parts which ſerve for reſpiration, that through weakneſs it is not able to draw the aliment to it ſelf, and convert it into blood.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: It is good for him who hath a wateriſh dropping and running of the eys, if he be taken with a flux and looſneſs of the belly.
Whereby Hippocrates ſhews us a convenient way how to cure ſuch eys, namely by drawing the humors which cauſe the diſeaſe downwards

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p:
It is a deadly thing when the bladder is wounded, or the brain, or the heart, the midriff, any ſmall
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
gut, the Stomack or Liver.
The Greek word for wounded is here 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which ſignifies deep wounded; for otherwiſe ſome of thoſe parts have been wounded and cured as Galen ſaith.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: A bone periſhed or cut off, a cartilage, griſtle, or ſinew, or any little parcel of the eye-lid, or of the foreskin, being diminiſhed, do not grow or joyn together.

p.hi: Yet they may be knit together by ſome other kind of ſubſtance as we ſee in bones.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: If blood flow contrary to nature into any concavity it corrupteth and is putrified of neceſſity.

p.hi: That is, into any other concavity beſides the veins and arteries.

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p:
If the ſwellings of veins in the legs, called varices; or the Haemorroides,
ſhall happen to them which are mad, their madneſs is diſſolved.

p.hi: Becauſe nature drives thoſe humors which cauſe madneſs into the more ignoble parts.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: Breaches or fluxes of humors, which deſcend from the back to the elbow, are diſſolved by opening of a vein.

p.hi: By reaſon that thoſe humors are thereby evacuated.

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p: If fear and ſadneſs continue long, it is a ſign of melancholly.

p.hi: Namely without any outward cauſe, for thoſe who are ſad or fearful for any outward cauſe, their ſadneſs and fear do not commonly laſt long; but if they do, they will turn to melancholly, if not to madneſs.

div.head: APH. 24▪
div.p: If any ſmall or ſlender gut be pierced, it doth not grow together again.
This was ſpoken Aphoriſm 18. wherefore Galen and Heurnius would have it expunged.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: If the cholerick tumor Eryſipulas being outward be returned inwards, it is evil; but if being inwards, it is turned outward, it is a good thing.
By this example Hippocrates ſhews that it is good to have all ſores and diſeaſes of tbe body to come from the noble and inward parts to the ignoble and outward ones.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: Thoſe burning feavers are diſſolved with dotage or raving, in which are trembling ſhakings.

p.hi:
They are indeed diſſolved, but that diſſolution at laſt brings a general
diſſolution of the body by death

div.head: APH. 27
div.p: If the corruption, matter, or water do flow out altogether at once from them which are burnt or cauterized, or cut by the Chirurgion for the cure of the inward apoſthumation between▪ the lungs and the breaſt, or of the Dropſie, then the diſeaſed ſhall queſtionleſs die▪
By theſe examples Hippocrates ſhews that all total evacuations made at once, are noxious and deadly.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: Eunuchs or gelded men, are neither troubled with the Gout, nor with baldneſs.

p.hi:
Becauſe in Hippocrates time they uſed a very good diet, and lived very temperately they were not troubled with the gout, though now adays they be, and their not being
bald comes from their native moiſture, which makes them have a very thick skin.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: A woman is not troubled with the Gout unleſs her monthly terms fail her.

p.hi: The ſame reaſons may be alleadged for women as were ſet down in the former, for Eunuchs. But if her terms fail her, then the ſuperfluous humors being driven to the outward parts may cauſe it.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: A boy is not troubled with the Gout till he hath uſed Venery.

p.hi: Ʋnleſs it come through their ſeed, or if the parents have had the French pox.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: Drinking of ſtrong wine, a ba •• , a fomentation, phlebotomy, or a purgation doth cure the pain of the eyes.

p.hi: According as the cauſe of the diſeaſe is, ſo muſt the manner of the taking of it away be various.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Thoſe which ſtammer are for the moſt part taken with a long flux of the belly.

p.hi: Becauſe ſtammering ſhews an extraordinary humidity of the tongue, whereof the ventricle of neceſſity participates.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: Thoſe which have ſour belchings are not much ſubject to a Pluriſie.

p.hi: Becauſe ſour belching is a ſign of much phlegm, and the Pluriſie for the moſt part invades thoſe who are troubled with much choller.

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: Great ſwelling veins in the legs called varices, are not incident to them who loſe their hair, and if they happen to have varices whoſe hair do fall, their hair will grow again.

p.hi: Becauſe thoſe vicious humors which before corrupted the hair, are now gon down into the legs.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: If a cough come upon thoſe which are troubled with a Dropſie it is an evil thing.

p.hi: For it ſignifies the watery humor to be ſo increaſed, that it hath ſeiſed upon the rough artery, and ſo cauſeth danger of ſuffocation.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: Phlebotomy cureth the difficulty of making urine, but we muſt open the inward veins.

p.hi: Namely that difficulty which proceeds from inflamation or fulneſs

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p: If a tumor appear in the neck to him that is troubled with a Squinancy or Quinzy, it is good.

p.hi: Becauſe the humors are come from the inward parts to the outward.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: Thoſe who have hidden or deep Cancers are not to be cured of them; for they which are healed die ſoon, and thoſe which are not healed, live longer.

p.hi: For fear of provoking or irritating them.

div.head: APH▪ 39.
div.p: A Convulſion is cauſed by repletion or evacuation. So is alſo the Hicket.
Namely when the nerves are filled with ſome thick or clammy humor, or over dryed. And the Hicket is ſaid by Galen to be as it were a Convulſion of the ſtomack.

div.head: APH. 40.
div.p: They who have pain about the the hypocondrium without an inflammation are cured by a Feaver happening to them.

p.hi: Becauſe the humors which cauſed it are diſſolved by the heat of the Feaver.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If a ſuppuration or corrupt matter, hidden in the body doth not ſhew it ſelf, it is by reaſon either of its own thickneſs, or of that part of the bodies thickneſs where it lies hidden.

p.hi: Yet we may find that there is ſuch corrupt matter hidden by two ſigns namely by the pain, and by a Feaver which it cauſeth.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p: If the Liver wax hard to them which are affected with the yellow-Jaundies, it is an evil ſign.

p.hi: For it ſignifies there is either a hard tumor or an inflammation in the Liver

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: The ſplenetick which are taken with a bloody-flux in the bowel, do dye of the Dropſie, or a ſlipperineſs of the bowels, following a long flux.

p.hi: By ſplenetick he means thoſe who have a tumor in the spleene, bred there, by a melancholly humor.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: They dye within ſeven days, to whom the diſeaſe called Ileos or pain in the ſmall guts ſhall happen after a Strangurie: unleſs a Feaver ſupervening, ſtore of urine iſſue forth.

p.hi: For the Fe ••• er with its heat concocts and ex •••• ates the thick humors, ſo that they may go out through the paſſage of the urine.

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p: If ulcers continue a yeer or longer, the bone of neceſſity muſt grow foul, and the Cicatrices be hollow.

p.hi: Becauſe the bone being periſhed under, the fleſh cannot grow up again as was ſaid Aph. 19. of this Section.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Thoſe which become Crookbackt by ſhortneſs of wind, or a cough before they attain to ripeneſs of years, doe die quicklie.

p.hi: Becauſe their breſt or bulk doth not increaſe as their lungs and heart doth, they muſt in a ſhort time to ſuffocated.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: Thoſe are to be let blood or purged in the Spring time, to whom opening of a vein or purging may do good.

p.hi: For the Spring time being temperate is moſt fit for purging or leting blood.

div.head: APH. 48.
div.p: The difficulty of the inteſtines & guts, coming upon them which are diſeaſed with the ſpleen is good.
Becauſe the thick and melancholly humors are thereby eva • uated as Aph. 4 •

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: Goutie diſeaſes, the inflammation being aſſwaged, within fortie dayes deceaſe.

p.hi: For the inflammation wil be cured within forty dayes, if the Phyſitian preſcribe right, and the patient be truly obedient.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: It muſt needs be, that a Feaver, and Vomiting of choller muſt come upon them, which have their brain wounded.

p.hi: A Feaver, becauſe any principall members inflammation cauſeth a Feaver, and the vomiting of Choller becauſe of the conſent and agreement which is between the braine and the ſtomack, to which ſome of the great nerves diſcend from the braine.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p:
Thoſe which are in health being ſodainly taken with the head-ache,
and preſently become dumb and ſnort, die within ſeven days, unleſs a Feaver come upon them in the mean while.

p.hi: Becauſe the Feaver heats, attenuates and reſolves the windie ſpirit and the pituitous humors which cauſe theſe ſymptomes.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: We muſt conſider in their ſleeps if any part of the eyes appear; for if any of the white of them appears, the eye lidds not being faſt cloſed, if it doe not happen by a Flux of the bellie, or by the taking of ſome medicinall potion, it is an evil and verie deadly ſigne.

p.hi: If it happen not through ſome externall cauſe, for it ſignifies an imbecillitie of the facultie which moves the eye lids.

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p:
That doting which is done with aughter is not ſo dangerous, as
that which is done with earneſt ſadneſſe.

p.hi: For it does not proceed from ſo aduſt a Choler, as that which is done with earneſt ſadneſs.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Painfull breathings in ſharp diſeaſes with a Feaver, as it were of ſuch as ſigh, and mourne, are evill.

p.hi: For it ſignifies either a hardneſs of the nerves or muſcles, or a weakeneſs of naturall ſtrength, or ſome affect that cauſeth paine, or is convulſory.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Paine of the Gout doe moſt commonly afflict, and are provoked in the Spring and Autumn.

p.hi:
In Spring becauſe the humors gathered together in the winter are expelled from the ſtronger parts to the weaker; and in Autumn by reaſon of its inequalitie, and becauſe
the evill humors gathered together by eating of fruits in Summer▪ ſettle in thoſe we akeſt parts.

div.head: APH. 56.
div.p: The falling down of humors are verie dangerous in melancholie diſeaſes at thoſe ſeaſons. And declare an Appoplexie, or a convulſion, or maddneſs or blindneſs.

p.hi: If they fall down to the ventricles of the brain, they cauſe an Apoplexie if to the nerves a convulſion, if to the ſubſtance of the braine madneſs, if to the eyes blindneſs.

div.head: APH 57,
div.p: Apoplexies are cauſed moſt eſpeciallie from the fortieth to the ſixtieth year.

p.hi: He means thoſe Apoplexies which proceed from melancholie, which in thoſe times abound in our bodies.

div.head: APH. 58▪
div.p: If the Call hang foorth of the bodie, it muſt of neceſſity putrefie.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This ſeaventh Section is altogether prognoſticall and foretelling things to come, and herein he intreateth of preſages of health and death.

div.head: APHORISM. 1.
div.p: COldneſs of the extreame parts in ſharp diſeaſes is evill.

p.hi: Becauſe is ſhews there is a mightie • nflamation in ſome of the inward parts, which like a cupping glaſſe draws all the blood to it, and ſo leaves the extream parts cold.

div.head: APH. 2.
div.p: Fleſh black and blew becauſe of a foule diſeaſed bone, is an evill thing,

p.hi: For it ſhews there is a great putrefaction of the bone, and extinction of the natural heat.

div.head: APH, 3.
div.p: The hicket and redneſs of the eyes after vomiting are evill

p.hi: For theſe two together ſhew there is a great inflamation, either in the ventricle or the braine.

div.head: APH. 4▪
div.p: After ſweate, cold ſhiverings and ſhakings are not good.

p.hi: For it is a ſigne that nature is weake, and that the ſweat hath not had power to drive out all the noxious humors.

div.head: APH. 5.
div.p: After madneſs, a bloodie Flux, the dropſie, or an extanſie or trane is good.

p.hi: For it ſignifieth that the noxious humors are gone from the head to the lower parts

div.head: APH. 6.
div.p: Abhorring of meat in a long diſeaſe, and the excrements avoided down without mixture of humors, are evill.

p.hi: Becauſe, it ſhews the inbecilitie of the concocting facultie, and that all natural humidity is dried up by the ſeaveriſh heat.

div.head: APH. 7.
div.p: Cold ſhakings, and fond dotings, after much drinking of wine are evill▪

p.hi: The firſt by reaſon, it is a ſigne that the native heat is extinguiſht by the much drinking of wine. And the doting proceeds from the heads being full of fervent blood and vapour.

div.head: APH. 8.
div.p:
After the breaking of an impoſthume
inwardly faintneſſe; vomiting and ſwouning.

p.hi: He ſpeakes here of the breaking of impoſthumes which break in the ſtomack, for the ſymptome of vomiting followes none elſe.

div.head: APH. 9
div.p: After a Flux of blood, a Delirium or raveing, or a convulſion are evill.

p.hi: For it ſhews a great drought of the bodie, and weakneſs of the brains forces.

div.head: APH. 10▪
div.p: After the Iliack paſſion, or colick the hicket, raveing, or convulſion are evil.

p.hi: Which are cauſed by the foulneſs of the ſtomack and conſent which is between the braine and the ſtomack.

div.head: APH. 11.
div.p: After a pleuriſie, an Inflamation of the lungs is evill.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies that part of the noxious humors is gone from the Ieſs noble part of the ribbs, to the more noble viz. the lungs.

div.head: APH. 12.
div.p: A phrenſie after an inflamation of the lungs is evill.

p.hi: The inflamation of the lungs, ſending up vapours into the head, and they poſſeſſing the braine cauſe a Phrenſie.

div.head: APH. 13.
div.p: A Convulſion, or the Cramp, after hot burnings, are evill,

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies a great dryneſs of the nerves or ſinewes.

div.head: APH. 14.
div.p: Aſtoniſhment and raving through ſome blow of the head is an evill ſigne.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies that the wound hath penetrated to the • raine▪

div.head: APH. 15.
div.p: The ſpitting out of corrupt matter, after the ſpitting of blood is evill.

p.hi: Becauſe it ſignifies that the lungs are exulcerated.

div.head: APH. 16.
div.p: A conſumption▪ and a Flux of the haire or of the bellie, coming after the ſpitting of corrupt matter are evilſignes, for when the ſpitting is ſtopped, the diſeaſed doe die.

p.hi: The firſt part of this Aphoriſme is averred, Aphoriſm. 11. and 12. of the 5 Section, to which we referr you. The reaſon of the ſecond part is becauſe if the ſpitting be ſtopped, the lungs are ſo oppreſſed with the abundance of flegme lying on them, that the patient is ſuffocated and ſtrangled, for want of breath.

div.head: APH. 17.
div.p: The hicket comming through an inflamation of the liver is evill.

p.hi: For it ſhews the greatneſs of the inflamation, of which the ſtomack alſo participates, and being bitten by ſtore of choller ſwiming in it, it cauſes the hicket,

div.head: APH. 18.
div.p: A convulſion or raving cauſed through watching is an evill thing▪

p.hi: For watching doth extreamly evacuate and exiccate the body; which cauſeth both the raving and convulſion.

div.head: APH. 19.
div.p: After the laying bare of a bone, the inflamation and hot tumor Eriſipelas is evill.

p.hi: For it ſheweth a confluction thither of hot blood and choler, which corrode, and conſume the adjacent fleſh.

div.head: APH. 20.
div.p: Putrefaction or impoſtumation after, from the inflamation Eriſipelas is evill,

p.hi: For it ſhews the malignitie of the ſaid Eriſipelas, which doth not only exulcerate the upper parts of the bodie, but feeds deeper in, and creeps on to the ſound parts

div.head: APH. 21.
div.p: A Flux of blood, after a ſtrong pulſe in vlcers is evill.

p.hi: Firſt becauſe it ſhews an extreame inflamation to be joyned to the ulcer; ſecondly becauſe this eruption or Flux cannot be, unleſs the month of the artery be opened: which is very difficult to be ſtopped.

div.head: APH. 22.
div.p: After a long paine of the parts belonging to the bellie, an impoſthumation is evill.

p.hi: Which it muſt needs come to at laſt▪ unleſs death of the patient prevent it

div.head: APH. 23.
div.p:
After avoiding of unmixed excrements
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
downwards, a bloodie Flux is evill

p.hi: For ſuch humors will erode and periſh ſome parts of the inteſtines.

div.head: APH. 24.
div.p: Raving or Delirium enſues after the wound of a bone, if it penetrate into the hollow or void ſpace.

p.hi: He ſpeaks here of the bones of the head onely, as appears by the 14. Aph.

div.head: APH. 25.
div.p: A convulſion after the taking of a purging potion bringeth death.

p.hi: Becauſe is ſignifies an incurable drought.

div.head: APH. 26.
div.p: A great cold of the uttermoſt parts, through vehement paine of the parts belonging to the bellie is evill.

p.hi: The reaſon whereof is ſet downe in the comment of the 1. Aphoriſm of this Sect.

div.head: APH. 27.
div.p: If the diſeaſe called Teneſmus ſhall happen to a woman with child, it is the cauſe of abortment.

p.hi: This Teneſmus is a great provocation or deſire to goe to ſtoole, and when they come thither can doe nothing.

div.head: APH. 28.
div.p: If either a bone, cartilage or ſinew, ſhall be cut in the bodie, it doth neither increaſe nor grow together againe.

p.hi: This was ſpoken afore in the 19. Aphoriſm Sect 6.

div.head: APH. 29.
div.p: If a ſtrong Flux of the bellie ſhall come upon him that is diſeaſed, with a dropſie called Leacophlegmatia, it diſſolveth and cureth the diſeaſe.

p.hi: Becauſe it evacuates the efficient cauſe of the diſeaſe, which is abundance of white flegme, from whence alſo comes the diſeaſes name.

div.head: APH. 30.
div.p: They have a falling down of flegmatick humors from the head, which doe a vid froathie excrements out of the bellie.

p.hi: For phlegmatick humors being windie, it is no marvell if they be froathie.

div.head: APH. 31.
div.p: Sediments in urines, made in the time of agues like unto courſe wheat-meal doe ſignifie that the ſickneſs ſhall continue long.

p.hi: For it ſhews a kind of groſs thick humor, which cannot be diſolved or voided in a ſhort ſpace.

div.head: APH. 32.
div.p: Cholerick ſediments in urins, which at the firſt were thinn, doe ſignifie a ſharp diſeaſe.

p.hi: For choller always cauſeth ſharp diſeaſes. And urines are always faithfull meſſengers of the affections of the veines.

div.head: APH. 33.
div.p: Thoſe which makes diverſe urines, have a vehement diſturbance in their bodie.

p.hi: For when the urines are ſo, it ſhews a manifoldneſs of humors to be viciouſly diſeaſed

div.head: APH. 34.
div.p: The urins in which bubbles doe ſwim a loft, ſignifie a diſeaſe of the reins, and that the diſeaſe will endure long.

p.hi: For thoſe bubbles proceding from humiditie which is extended about by a flatuous ſpirit, doe cauſe a cold diſeaſe which cold diſeaſes are long.

div.head: APH. 35.
div.p: Thoſe to whom a fattneſs ſwims upon their vrine together & on a ſodain, it is a ſigne the diſeaſe is in the reins, and aſharp one too.

p.hi:
For if the diſeaſe were in the whole bodie, it would come forth by little and little, and it is a ſharp
one, for the head of it melts the fat of the reins.

div.head: APH. 36.
div.p: If alſo paines be cauſed to thoſe which are diſeaſed with the grief of the kidneys about the muſcles of the back bone, and have the ſignes aboveſaid, if they be felt towards the outward parts, look and expect that the impoſthume ſhall be alſo outwardly. But if the pains bend and decline rather to the inward parts, we muſt then expect the impoſthume will be inwards

p.hi: Namely if the paine hath been long and great.

div.head: APH. 37.
div.p: Vomiting of blood is wholſome to them which doe it without a Feaver: but if it be with a Feaver it is an evill thing, and the cure and remedie of the ſame, is to be performed with things that have a cooling and binding • ualitie.

p.hi: All vomits of blood are bad, Sect. 4. Aphoriſme. 25, therefore this muſt be here underſtood comparatively, namely that it is more tolerable without, then with a Feaver.

div.head: APH. 38.
div.p: Diſtillations upon the upper bellie come to ſuppuration and ripeneſs within twenty dayes.

p.hi: By the upper belly, he means the ſtomach, whoſe heat cauſeth the ſuppuration to be made ſo ſoon.

div.head: APH 39
div.p: If any one piſs blood, or clots of blood, and be diſeaſed with the Strangury, the pain falling into the Perinaeum, Hypogaſtrium, and Pectinem, the places and part about the bladder are diſeaſed.

Perinaeum is the part between the privie Members and the Fundament. Hypogaſtrium the bottome of the belly: And Pecten
that part under the bellie where the haire grows.

div.head: APH. 40
div.p: If a mans tongue ſodainly become feeble, or any part of the body benummed without feeling, it is a ſigne of melancholie.

p.hi: For they proceeded from a thick juice which is partly melancholie partlie phlegmatick.

div.head: APH. 41.
div.p: If the hicket happen to old men, purged above meaſure it is not good.

p.hi: Becauſe ſuch a hicket is bad in all, eſpeciallie in old men, becauſe in them all diſeaſes are greater, and more to he doubted by reaſon of the imbecilitie of that age.

div.head: APH. 42.
div.p: If the feaver be not cauſed by choller, much warm water poured upon the head doth diſolve it.

p.hi: Ʋnder the name of choler • e doth here comprehend all other humors, as Phlegme, blood and black choler.

div.head: APH. 43.
div.p: A woman hath not the uſe of both hands alike,

p.hi: By reaſon of the imbecilitie of womans nature.

div.head: APH. 44.
div.p: If a cleare and white matter doe iſſue out from them which are affected with corrupt matter, when they ſuffer cauterizing or inciſion, they doe eſcape: but if bloodie, ſtinking, and filthy matter doe iſſue forth, they die.

p.hi: By being affected with corrupt matter he means all which have anie corrupt tumor, but eſpecially ſuch as have it gathered between the lungs and the breſt,

div.head: APH. 45.
div.p:
If clear and white matter doe
iſſue from them whoſe liver is corrupted, and is burnt, they recover health: for the corrupt matter is contained in the coat, but if that which cometh forth be like the lees of oyle they die.

p.hi: The reaſon of the Aphoriſm is ſet down in it, when he ſaith, the matter is contained in the coat, for if it penetrate into the fleſh or ſubſtance of the liver they dye.

div.head: APH. 46.
div.p: Cure and heale pains of the eyes, which proceed from drinking of ſtrong wine▪ and bathing in hot water, by opening of a veyne.

p.hi: This Aphoriſme is by Gallen and Heurnius held to be ſpurious and not worthy of Hypocrates; alludes to the 31. Aphoriſm of the 6 Section, yet it much differs from it.

div.head: APH. 47.
div.p: If a cough come upon one diſeaſed with the dropſie, he is irrecoverable

p.hi: This and the 35 Aphoriſme of the 6 Section are all one.

div.head: APH. 48
div.p: Drinking of neat ſtrong wine, and the opening of a veine diſſolves the Strangurie and Dyſurie, but the inward veins muſt be opened.

p.hi: He ſpeakes not of all Stranguries and Dyſuries, but only of that Strangurie or dropping of urine, which is cauſed by coldneſs, and of that Dyſurie, or the urines painful comming out, which proceeds from a viſcous and flatuous humor.

div.head: APH. 49.
div.p: A ſwelling and redneſs ariſing on the breſt of him who have a Squiancie is good, for the diſeaſe inclineth outwards.

p.hi: This differs nothing from the 37 of the ſixt Section, but only in the place of the redneſſes ariſing, ſo that in both, Hippocrates ſcope is to ſhew that in this diſeaſe it is good to have thè humors tend outward.

div.head: APH. 50.
div.p: They die within three dayes, whoſe braine begins to corrupt, but if they overpaſſe them, they ſhall recover their health.

p.hi: Becauſe the brain is a principal and moſt noble part: But if they ſcape three daies it may be hoped, the diſeaſe may remitt and that the naturall forces will ouercome it.

div.head: APH. 51.
div.p: Sneezing is provoked out of the head, the brain being much heated, or the void ſpace of the head being much moiſtned: For the aire incloſed within, doth breake forth; and it makes a noiſe becauſe it paſſeth through a narrow place.

p.hi: He ſpeaks in this Aphoriſme only of that ſneezing which is cauſed by the motion if nature deſires to driue out flatuous ſpirit out of the head.

div.head: APH. 52.
div.p: Thoſe who are grieved with vehement pain of the Liver, are delivered from it, if an Ague come upon them.

p.hi: Which vehement pain cometh by windineſs which the feaver diſperſes

div.head: APH. 53.
div.p: Thoſe which have occaſion to have blood taken from them, muſt be let blood in the Spring.

p.hi: This is part of the Aph. 47. Sect. 6 look upon that's Comment.

div.head: APH. 54.
div.p: Thoſe which have phlegm incloſed between the ventricle and the middriff, which is painful to them, having no paſſage into either of the bellies, are delivered from the diſeaſe, the phlegm being turned through the veins into the body.

p.hi:
Matter may come out of the veins into any place of the body, and being
extenuated return into them again.

div.head: APH. 55.
div.p: Thoſe have their belly filled with water and die, whoſe Liver repleniſht with water, makes an eruption of it in the upper part of the belly where the Caul is.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm ſpeaks what is for the moſt part, for by the help of nature and medicaments ſuch may be cured.

div.head: APH. 56.
div.p: Wine being drunk with an equal proportion of water, puts away ſorrow, yawning, and cold ſhaking

p.hi: For wine by its moderate heat expels moſt of thoſe matters which cauſe theſe ſymptomes and tempereth the reſt.

div.head: APH. 57.
div.p: Thoſe which have a little ſwelling in the urinary paſſage, they are delivered from it, the ſame being brought to ſuppuration and broken.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm is the ſame as the 82 of the fourth Secton where it was explained.

div.head: APH. 58.
div.p: They muſt of neceſſity become dumb preſently, which have their brain vehemently ſhaken & troubled by ſome outward occaſion.

p.hi: In the word dumbneſs he here comprehends all other voluntary motions.

div.head: APH. 59.
div.p: Hunger and faſting is to be indured by bodies conſiſting of moiſt fleſh. For faſting dryeth the body.

p.hi: He means ſo much faſting as will ſerve to correct the humidity of the fleſh.

div.head: APH. 60.
div.p: Where there is alteration in the whole body, and it becometh cold and hot again, or changeth from one colour to another, it ſigniſies length of the diſeaſe.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm is repeated from that which is Sect. 4. Aph. 40.

div.head: APH. 61.
div.p: Much ſweat hot and dry frequently iſſuing forth, declares abundance of moiſtneſs, which in a ſtrong body is to be vacuated upwards, in a weak one downwards.

This Aphoriſm is thought by Galen to be ſpurious, and alſo the three following, yet Heurnius ſaith no ſuch thing. But ſaith this Aphoriſm means that ſweat which proceeds from ſuperabundance of moiſture, and not from plenty of food.

div.head: APH. 62.
div.p: If Agues become more fierce and vehement every third day without intermiſſion they are dangerous. But in what manner ſoever they ſhall ceaſe it ſignifieth they are void of danger.

div.head: APH. 63.
div.p:
Thoſe which are afflicted with
long Feavers have little ſwellings or aches in the joynts.

div.head: APH. 64.
div.p: Thoſe which have long ſwellings or pains in the joynts after a Feaver, do uſe too plentiful a diet.

p.hi: Theſe three laſt Aphoriſms are the ſame with the 43, 44, and 45 of the fourth Section, where they have been already explained.

div.head: APH. 65.
div.p: If any give the meat to one ſick of a Feaver, which he giveth to a healthful perſon, he ſhall ſtrengthen the healthful perſon, and increaſe the malady of the ſick.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm alſo is falſly imputed to Hippocrates.

div.head: APH. 66.
div.p:
We muſt look upon thoſe things which paſs through the bladder, whether they be ſuch as iſſue forth in proſperous health. For thoſe which are unlike them, are unhealthful
ſignes, but thoſe which are like them, are healthful ſignes.
This Aphoriſm ſpeaks that which Hippocrates in a manner ſpeaks elſewhere: yet becauſe it hath neither the form nor phraſe of Hippocrates, Galen rejects it.

div.head: APH. 67.
div.p: Alſo when the ſediments, if thou ſhalt ſuffer them to reſt, and ſhalt not move them, do ſink down into the bottom like ſhavings of guts or ſuch like matter, if they be few, they ſignifie the diſeaſe is but little; but if they be many, that it is great Then it is neceſſary to evacuate the belly downwards; otherwiſe if thou ſhalt give broth and nouriſhments, without purging the belly, the more thou giveſt, the more thou ſhalt offend.
This Aphoriſm Galen holds to be foiſted in by ſome ſophiſter and lover of obſcurity and to be none of Hippocrates.

div.head: APH. 68.
div.p: Crude, raw and undigeſted excrements voided downwards, do proceed from black choller. If they be many, they proceed from a more copious quantity, if they be few, from a leſſer.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm participates of the formers obſcurity, and by ſome is joyned to it and made the latter part of the other.

div.head: APH. 69.
div.p: Spittings, in Feavers not intermitting, aſh-coloured bloodyiſh, cholerick, ſtinking, are all evil. But if they come forth conveniently and eaſily they are good, whether they iſſue out by the belly or bladder. And if any thing ſtays unpurged which ſhould have come forth, it is evil.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm is in a manner the ſame with the 47 of the fourth Section

div.head: APH. 70.
div.p: When any one goeth about to purge unclean bodies, he muſt make them ſoluble and fluxible.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm hath alſo been explained in the tenth Aph. of the ſecond Section.

div.head: APH. 71.
div.p: Sleep and watchfulneſs, if they exceed a meaſure, are a diſeaſe.

p.hi: This is alſo the ſame Aphoriſm in ſubſtance with the third of the ſecond Section,

div.head: APH. 72.
div.p: In Feavers not intermitting, if the exterior parts be cold, and the inward burning and the patient have a Feaver.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm was better ſet down Sect. 4. Aph. 48. for why ſhould he add at the end of this, if the patient have a Feaver when he had already ſaid in the beginning, In Feavers not intermitting.

div.head: APH. 73.
div.p: In a Feaver not intermitting, if a lip, noſe, eye, or eye-brow be perverted and turned awry, if the ſick man do not ſee nor hear, whatſoever of theſe things ſhall happen to a weak ſick man, death is neer at hand.

p.hi: This Aphoriſm is the ſame with the 49 of Sect. 4.

div.head: APH. 74.
div.p: After white phlegme comes a Dropſie.

p.hi: Namely when the body and its veſſels, are abundantly filled with it

div.head: APH. 75.
div.p: From a looſeneſs of the belly, proceeds a bloody-flux.

p.hi: Not from all looſneſſes, but onely ſuch as are long laſting, and bilious as Aph 23.

div.head: APH. 76.
div.p: After a bloody-flux comes a Lienteria.

p.hi: Which is a flux of undigeſted meat. See Sect. 6. Aph. 43.

div.head: APH. 77.
div.p: After the corruption of the bone comes the impoſt humation of it called in Greek Sphaceliſmos.

p.hi: It may be alſo taken for a Gangrening of the fleſh about it.

div.head: APH▪ 78.
div.p: After vomiting of blood, a Conſumption, and an evacuation of filthy purulent matter doth enſue.
This Aphoriſm is ſet down ſeveral ways, but I have followed Galens expoſition.

div.head: APH. 79.
div.p:
We ought to behold what things they be which paſs out by urines or by the belly, and what things iſſue out through the fleſh. And we muſt alſo conſider and behold whether the body do decline in any other thing from nature. For if little be a voided the diſeaſe is
little, if much, the diſeaſe is great, and if very much it is deadly.

p.hi: To the end that the Phyſician may know the diſeaſe, he muſt take ſpecial notice of the excrements, and examine them in ſubſtance, quantity, quality, and the time and manner of getting them out. For the excrements repreſent the Idea of thoſe parts from whence they proceed.
